intro: Enarthrocarpus strangulatus var. perocarpoides, commonly known as the red mangosteen, is a tropical plant native to Southeast Asia. It is a small evergreen tree characterized by its glossy, dark green leaves and striking red, fleshy fruits. The fruit has a thick, segmented pericarp that splits open when mature, revealing a segmented, edible aril surrounding the seeds. The plant thrives in humid, coastal environments and is often found in mangrove ecosystems. Its botanical features make it an important species in both ecological and horticultural contexts.
